children.value: Requires: a connection between client and server
Stateless: no login process, each request is independent
Simple format: request header, blank line, possible payload
Symmetrical: allows data to be sent and recieved
Very easy to implement but scales very well
What do each of these headers mean? Which are required? Many are defined in the
but others can be defined via the HTTP extension framework.
This is a POST request, note how the data is encoded in the request body.

This is the same form submitted via a GET request, here the data is encoded in request URL. Note also the If-Modified-Since header in this request, sent because my browser has just asked for the same resource.

The HTTP redirect is a server response that can be used to indicate that a resource has moved to a new location. An alternate is to include the above meta tag in a page header to force a redirect from the current page.
POST - send some data to a resource
HEAD - get headers for a resource
- Request succeeded and everything went well
- Requested resource has moved and all future requests should be made to new location
- Response refused by server (even if request is valid)
- Server could not find requested resource (though it may be available in the future)
- Generic error message response when server encountered an error
full list of HTTP status codes
in Firefox to view headers of requests that you make. Also available as a
in the Developer tools allows you to view the request headers and content for each request that was made when you're looking at a page.
gives a good overview of the protocol.
